dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: People think the Fed's rate hikes are all about inflation, but actually, they're also removing language about being accommodative, which is a huge signal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: People think the Fed's rate hikes are all about inflation, but actually, they're also removing language about being accommodative, which is a huge signal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The FOMC also removed a sentence from its statement that had said monetary policy remains accommodative, although Chairman Jerome Powell said in his post-meeting press conference that this does not mean that the Fed will not respond to negative economic developments.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and Jerome Powell specifically said that doesn't mean they won't respond to negative economic developments. It's like, they're trying to be more data-dependent now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and Jerome Powell specifically said that doesn't mean they won't respond to negative economic developments. It's like, they're trying to be more data-dependent now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The FOMC also removed a sentence from its statement that had said monetary policy remains accommodative, although Chairman Jerome Powell said in his post-meeting press conference that this does not mean that the Fed will not respond to negative economic developments.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And with unemployment at 4.0%, which is basically full employment by historical standards, they're really watching for overheating.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And with unemployment at four point zero percent, which is basically full employment by historical standards, they're really watching for overheating.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At 3.9%, unemployment is arguably at a rate that in the past has marked full employment, and prices of goods, labor, and assets are rising across the board.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But then there's this whole thing about the yield curve flattening, right? Which has been a recession predictor in the past.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then there's this whole thing about the yield curve flattening, right? Which has been a recession predictor in the past.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the immediate aftermath of the Feds move, the yield curve grew flatter as short-term rates rose while longer-term rates did not move or fell slightly. Although short-term rates remain below long-term rates, an inverted yield curve in which the opposite is true has historically been highly correlated with subsequent economic downturns.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, uh, short-term rates are rising but long-term ones aren't keeping up. That inversion worry is definitely on investors' minds.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, uh, short-term rates are rising but long-term ones aren't keeping up. That inversion worry is definitely on investors' minds.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the immediate aftermath of the Feds move, the yield curve grew flatter as short-term rates rose while longer-term rates did not move or fell slightly.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then you've got UBS pointing out that pricing growth for S&P 500 companies is at 3.5% year-over-year, which is above the Fed's target.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then you've got U B S pointing out that pricing growth for S&P five hundred companies is at three point five percent year-over-year, which is above the Fed's target.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A research note this week from UBS shows that pricing over the last three months for companies in the S&P 500 grew 3.3% from one year ago, 2.3% excluding the energy sector.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but wage growth is at 2.5%, which is down from earlier this year. The concern is if wages top 4%, profits could take a hit.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but wage growth is at two point five percent, which is down from earlier this year. The concern is if wages top four percent, profits could take a hit.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Wage growth for the S&P 500, excluding energy, is running at 2.4% a year, but down from highs earlier this year above 3%. UBS says that corporate profit cycles have historically turned lower once annual wage growth tops 4%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So it's like a balancing act. Some sectors are doing great though—energy, utilities, materials with pricing growth up to 21%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So it's like a balancing act. Some sectors are doing great though-energy, utilities, materials with pricing growth up to twenty one percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: UBS finds that energy, utilities, and materials enjoy the strongest profit margin tailwinds, thanks to pricing growth of 6% to 20%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And UBS even highlighted specific stocks they like—JPMorgan, Citigroup, Amazon, Warner Bros.—companies with strong pricing power.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And U B S even highlighted specific stocks they like-JPMorgan, Citigroup, Amazon, Warner Bros.-companies with strong pricing power.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Among those that make the cut are big banks like JPMorgan Chase & Co. (JPM), Citigroup (C), Wells Fargo & Co. (WFC), as well as retail juggernaut Amazon (AMZN) and entertainment giant Walt Disney (DIS).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is key because if inflation stays around 3%, you want investments that can keep up, maybe even dividend growers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is key because if inflation stays around three percent, you want investments that can keep up, maybe even dividend growers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Just as important as pricing power, is a demonstrated history of dividend growth that keeps shareholders ahead of inflation. That wasnt much of a hurdle in the past decade when inflation was at negligible rates, but now running at 3% per year, inflation should be a on your radar when you decide what to do with your money.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. It's not just about stocks performing well in high inflation; it's about which ones can actually pass on costs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. It's not just about stocks performing well in high inflation; it's about which ones can actually pass on costs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And with the trade tensions still looming, it adds another layer of uncertainty to all this.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And with the trade tensions still looming, it adds another layer of uncertainty to all this.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The trade skirmish between the United States and China on steel, aluminum, ...

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. Powell and the Fed have their hands full navigating all these signals.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. Powell and the Fed have their hands full navigating all these signals.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's a lot more nuanced than just 'rates up, economy down.'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's a lot more nuanced than just 'rates up, economy down.'
